titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Ethical Culture Fieldston School Records
1879-2017
MS 3042
titlestmt.author: Alexanne Levengood

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-01-26 10:47:29 -0500.

physdesc.extent: in 396 containers and 25 flat files, of various sizes.

did.physloc: Most of the materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact manuscripts@nyhistory.org prior to your research visit to coordinate access. Keep in mind that it will take between two (2) and five (5) business days for collections to arrive, and you should plan your research accordingly.
did.abstract: The records are the archives of the Ethical Cultural Fieldston School, documenting its history from the late 1870s to the early twenty-first century. The records relate to school governance and administration, academics, student life, extracurricular activities, special programming such as camps, parent-teacher association, buildings and facilities, publications, alumni relations, and more.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p:
This collection is owned by the New-York Historical Society. The copyright law of the United States governs the making of photocopies and protects unpublished materials as well as published materials. Unpublished materials created before January 1, 1978 cannot be quoted in publication without permission of the copyright holder. Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to 20 exposures of stable, unbound material per day.
Some of the material in the collection is restricted. Specifics are noted at the relevant record group level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The collection should be cited as: Ethical Culture Fieldston School records, MS 3042, New-York Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Archivist Alexanne Levengood arranged and described this collection in January 2018-June 2019.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The collection is arranged in eighteen record groups:
Record Group 1. Governance, administration, and 3-School affairs
Record Group 2. Early and defunct schools
Record Group 3. Fieldston School
Record Group 4. Midtown Ethical Culture School
Record Group 5. Fieldston Lower
Record Group 6. Camps and programs
Record Group 7. Parent and Teacher Association
Record Group 8. Alumni and alumni-relations
Record Group 9. Development and communications
Record Group 10. Buildings and grounds
Record Group 11. Print matter
Record Group 12. History of the Ethical Culture Schools
Record Group 13. Ethics Department and the Society for Ethical Culture
Record Group 14. Photographs
Record Group 15. Audiovisual (Restricted. See note at series level)
Record Group 16. Artifacts
Record Group 17. Digital formats (Restricted. See note at series level)
Record group 18. Student records (Restricted. See note at series level)

bioghist.head: Administrative History Note
bioghist.p:
The Ethical Culture Fieldston School is a private independent K-12 school with locations in Manhattan and the Bronx. The school has its origins in the Free Kindergarten, founded in Manhattan by Felix Adler in 1878. Soon after, the school expanded its grade levels and became the Workingman's School in an effort to provide education to the city's underprivileged children. In the 1890s, the school changed its name again to the Ethical Culture School (in reflection of its relationship to the Society for Ethical Culture, also founded by Adler) and began charging tuition.
In 1904, the school moved to a newly constructed building at 33 Central Park West, adjacent to the Society for Ethical Culture. This building housed all grade levels until the opening of a high school at the Fieldston campus in the Riverdale neighborhood of the Bronx in 1928. A second lower school also opened in Fieldston in 1932. In 2007, a new middle school was opened on the Riverdale campus.
For some early years of the school, classes were also conducted at a secondary location called the Branch School. An elementary education department called the Normal School or the Teacher Training Department operated from the 1890s to 1939. At various points in its history, the school has offered several summer and extracurricular programs, including a summer camp in Cooperstown, New York.
The schools have been guided by a Board of Governors, later renamed the Board of Trustees, as well as an overarching administrative department. For much of the twentieth century, this department was called the 3-School Administration, in reference to the Ethical Culture School, Fieldston Lower and Fieldston Upper. Administratively, the school was led by a rector from 1878 to 1942, as well as an educational director (later renamed head of school) from 1928 onward. Individual schools have each been led by a principal.
Founder Felix Adler served as rector from 1878-1933. He was succeeded by John L. Elliott, founder of the Hudson Guild, who served from 1933-1942. For many years, prominent members of the Society for Ethical Culture could be found acting as chairman of the Board of Governors or the educational director. Financial and administrative ties to the Society for Ethical Culture were formally dissolved in the 1990s.
Long-serving administrators include Educational Directors V.T. Thayer (1928-1948), Victoria Wagner (1954-1968), and Howard Radest (1979-1991); and Fieldston Upper Principal Luther Tate (1941-1966), the namesake of Tate Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
The Ethical Culture Fieldston School records provide information on the administrative and academic affairs of the school from the 1880s into the twenty-first century. Themes seen throughout include progressive education, independent school administration, curriculum creation, fundraising, and budgeting. The role of ethics, arts, or sports programs in the curriculum, and the school's response to greater societal issues such as wars, racism, poverty, and environmental concerns, are often addressed.
Pre-1940 materials in the collection strongly reflect the school's early interest in "manual training" through graphic arts, mechanics, and practical skills curriculum. Later records tend to reflect the school's interest in social progressivism and move toward a college preparatory focus. In addition, the collection contains materials related to extracurricular and summer programs in several record groups, but particularly in "RG 6: Camps and Programs." In addition, "RG 2: Early and Defunct Schools" contains records of the Normal Teacher Training Department.
Themes also seen throughout the collection include: changes in standardization of education and college admissions process (see especially the records of the Eight Year Study in "RG 3: Fieldston School"), the challenges of serving underprivileged communities in an elite institution, and the rise of student activism and a changing adolescent culture beginning in the late 1960s. This last is documented in particular through the protests of the Black and Latino Students Club in 1970, which are discussed in several record groups.
Materials relating to constituent management, particularly parental involvement in school and the maintenance of alumni relations, can be found in several record groups, but especially in "RG 8: Alumni and Alumni Relations" and in "RG 9: Development and Communications."
Information about physical locations at 33 Central Park West and the Fieldston campus in the Bronx can be found in "RG 10: Buildings and Grounds," as well as in "RG 14: Photographs" and in the Board of Governors and administration records in "RG 1: Governance, Administration, and 3-School Affairs." This includes images, architectural plans, and discussion of maintenance, budgets, and space usage.
While the philosophical influence of the Society for Ethical Culture can be seen in administrative and curriculum materials throughout the collection, directly related items consist of Society-produced ephemera, discussion of shared spaces at the Central Park West location, and the financial and legal documents detailing the dissolution of financial ties formalized in 1996.
Correspondence, meeting materials, and administrative documents make up much of the collection, along with ephemera, curriculum materials, student work, and a significant number of photographs. Most materials were created by the 3-School administration, or by the administration of individual schools, with some materials created or collected by teachers or students. Beginning in the 1980s, the Alumni Affairs department played a large role in growing the archival collection by saving contemporary items and collecting donations of older items from alumni and their descendants.
A very small amount of records relate to photographer Lewis Hine, who taught photography at the Ethical Culture School in the early twentieth century. "RG 14: Photographs" contains copy photographs and copy negatives, along with two photographs marked as possible Hine images. Other mentions of Hine in the collection are later correspondence related to archival inquiries or publicity efforts. Also, while there are very few items directly related to the school's many notable alumni, possible sources of information on individual students include class lists and student rosters from 1891 onward, as well as Fieldston yearbooks and the Fieldston News student newspaper after 1928 found in "RG 11: Print Matter."
More detailed information can be found in the description for each individual Record Group and Series. Researchers should be aware that Columbia University Rare Book & Manuscript Library holds the papers of founder Felix Adler (The Felix Adler papers, 1830-1933), as well as records relating to Adler's successor as rector, John Lovejoy Elliott, in the Hudson Guild records, 1896-1990s.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of The Ethical Culture Fieldston School, August 2017. Ethical Culture Fieldston also generously provided the funding to support the processing of the archive.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers. Access to certain materials are restricted; these restrictions are noted at the series level.
Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact manuscripts@nyhistory.org at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

did.unittitle: Record Group 1. Governance, administration, and 3-School affairs (1888-2016; 64.42 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: This record group primarily contains materials related to the governance and administration of the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools. Nearly all records were created in the twentieth century, with the bulk created between 1930 and 1999. Most records were created by the Board of Governors or the ECFS administration, and cover topics including finances, staffing, fund-raising, physical plant, technology, social issues, educational theory, and long-term planning. Files for head of school positions (rectors, superintendents, and 3-School directors) are also included. Common types of materials found throughout include meeting minutes, correspondence, and reports.

In addition, this record group contains information on faculty and staff, as well as student registration data, from all three schools. Principals' annual reports to the Board of Governors also provide information on individual schools. Other materials related to specific schools can be found in their respective record groups.

Generally, development and public relations materials can be found in Record Group 9: Development and Marketing, but some materials in RG1 relate to these efforts. (For example, discussion of publicity in Board of Governors minutes.)

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p:
This record group is arranged in six series:
Series I. Board of Governors
Series II. Rectors and Superintendent
Series III. 3-School administration
Series IV. Office of the 3-School Director
Series V. Admissions and registration
Series VI. Faculty and staff

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: This series is made up of materials related to the Board of Governors (renamed the Board of Trustees in 1996). Materials include items created by members of Board, as well as items created for use by the Board, such as administrative reports. Records were created between 1903 and 2001, with the bulk of materials in the series created sometime between 1930 and 1990. The majority of items are routine documents, such as meeting minutes and annual status reports, with some correspondence and notes from various chairmen of the Board, as well as long-time Board member Nanette Rothschild.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p:
This series is arranged in six subseries:
Subseries I.A. Board of Governors: Incorporation, by-laws, minutes, and finances
Subseries I.B. Committees
Subseries I.C. Reports from the Principals, Directors, and other administrative officers
Subseries I.D. Chairman of the Board - Marie S. Neuberger Papers
Subseries I.E. Chairman of the Board - Joseph Jablonower papers
Subseries I.F. Nanette F. Rothschild Papers

did.unittitle: Subseries I.A Board of Governors: Incorporation, by-laws, minutes, and finances

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries primarily contains minutes for meetings of the Board of Governors (later the Board of Trustees), accompanied by meeting agendas, reports from committees, supplementary meeting materials, and related correspondence. Frequent topics of discussion include finances, enrollment, scholarships, collection of tuition, fundraising, faculty and staff, and buildings and grounds.

While most minutes are concerned with strategy or administrative matters, discussions involving the ethics programs and educational philosophy are included. Issues of racial or economic diversity are also discussed, such as in a 1908 declaration of "non-discrimination by color."

Earlier Board records are more likely to concern individual families or faculty members, or quotidian school business, with discussions moving towards higher level issues throughout the twentieth century. Many files include Executive Committee information (earliest records use the name House Committee). Records from 1981 through 1987 consist of complete mailings sent to Board members. Minutes prior to 1945 are largely facsimiles, not original documents.
Board minutes can also be found in the papers of Chairmen of the Board subseries, or in the Office of the Director series.
Other than minutes, this subseries contains financial documents related to the Board, and some other miscellaneous Board materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged by type of document, and then chronologically within each group.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Types of materials in this subseries include minutes, reports, notes, and a small amount of correspondence, for Board-level committees. Some minutes and reports are found within the overall Board of Governors meeting minutes.

Executive Committee minutes cover similar high-level issues as the overall Board of Governors minutes. External events and issues are often reflected in school agenda items, such as in a 1968 mention of "Anti-War Activities" on campus.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: This subseries is divided into records of the Executive Committee and records of other committees, then arranged chronologically within each group.

Executive Committee minutes and correspondence (31 folders)

scopecontent.p: Files include the Ethical Culture Schools – District 9 Cooperative Program Annual Report, 1976-1977.

scopecontent.p: File include minutes, reports, and notes from the following committees: Director's Search Committee (1970-1979), Education Committee (1983-1990), Enrollment Committee (1949), Committee on Finance and Budget (1954), Finance Committee (1999), Committee on Organization of School (1932).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: File include minutes, reports, and notes from the following committees: Planning Committees (1982-1990), Principal's Search Committee (1986), Rectorship Committee (1945), Salary Review Committee (1964), and Structure Committees (1973-1978). Some minutes and reports are interfiled with overall Board of Governors meeting minutes.

did.unittitle: Subseries I.C Reports from the Principals, Directors, and other administrative officers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of reports on administrative and educational issues during the school year at Ethical Cultures Schools. Types of reports vary each year, but nearly all files contain an overall report from the 3-Schools director, along with individual school reports from principals, and sometimes reports from the assistant director, registrar or admissions departments. Many of the reports from the 1930s also have sections written by academic department heads, or reports from the Branch School. Towards the end of the twentieth century, all files begin to include reports from the alumni and development office and the director of admissions and financial aid.

Generally, each principal's report provides a summary of the year's events, departmental issues, new hires, and achievements in teacher and student performance. Reports from directors and assistant directors attempt to confront larger school issues, focusing on budgets, development, faculty and student morale, and facilities. Many reports provide thoughts on ethics issues, parental involvement in the schools, trends in educational theory, technology, and the school's response to larger events and issues, including World War II, the Civil Rights Movement, and the Vietnam War. Occasionally, the administration also makes recommendations or poses questions to the Board.

Earliest reports consist of a lengthy qualitative analysis and personal reflection, with a very small amount of quantitative information (often a college matriculation list). Through the twentieth century, written sections shorten and the amount of quantitative information and data tables increases. 1945 onward, Ethical Culture Schools reports include registration reports with enrollment data. Beginning in the late 1950s, reports of the assistant to the director include a good deal of financial and fundraising information. From the 1960s onward, each year contains a separate report from the registrar's office. Special or ad hoc reports become more common in the second half of the 20th century.
Some files include an accompanying letter from the director, and the 1973 report also includes a letter from the Board in response to the director's report.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: This subseries is divided into annual and special reports, then arranged chronologically within each group.

did.unittitle: Annual reports to the Board of Governors (15 folders)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The 1939-1940 Fieldston School report appendix includes sample forms, such as report cards.

did.unittitle: Annual reports to the Board of Governors (15 folders)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: 1960 Fieldston School report includes Report of the Committee on Academic Honesty.

did.unittitle: Annual reports to the Board of Governors

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: 1963-1964 director's report is titled, "After Civil Rights – What?" Civil rights are also discussed in the report of Fieldston Principal Luther Tate that year. During the late 1960s and early 1970s, reports contain considerable discussion of social justice issues and shifts in student behavior and family situations (for example, families with two parents working outside of the home).

did.unittitle: Annual reports to the Board of Governors (21 folders)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Report types become more varied during this time period. Examples include: 1978 reports from the director of the Fieldston day camp and from the coordinator of educational philosophy, a 1979 report on an "Intercultural Exchange Program" between Fieldston and P.S. 98, and a 1996 report titled "Technology at ECF – A Status Report." Long-range planning reports, Ethical Fieldston Fund information, and Parent & Teacher's Association reports are also seen. Computers and new technology are frequently discussed.

did.unittitle: Special reports to the Board of Governors (2 folders)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: One-off reports and memos to the board. Includes reports and memos from Luther Tate, Howard Radest, and Frank Karelson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Materials of Joseph Jablonower, including those created during his tenure as Chairman of the Board from 1945-1951.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: In this subseries, Board of Governors records are arranged chronologically, while correspondence subject files are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with Richard Ballou, Algernon Black (of the Society for Ethical Culture), Herman Jervix, Sidney Rogers, and Luther Tate on financial, administrative, and personnel issues. Also two folders of personal correspondence and documents and one folder congratulatory letters and telegrams upon Jablonower's appointment to Board of Examiners of the New York City public school system. Small amount of non-correspondence items, including ephemera, resumes, memorandum, and drafts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with administration, parents, the public, and other Board members, relating to Board of Governors business and Jablonower's role as chairman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note

did.unittitle: Society for Ethical Culture - Board of Trustees

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, minutes, and related documents for the Society for Ethical Culture Board of Trustees and the Executive Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Mostly correspondence, with some ephemera, news clippings, reports, and meeting minutes. Significant subjects include budgets, facilities and properties, the Parent & Teacher's Association, school programs and camps, and staffing (including discussions of salaries and of the rectorship, and the Educational Director search in 1947-1948).

did.unittitle: Subseries I.F Nanette F. Rothschild Papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise noted, materials generally consist of meeting minutes, documents, notes, news clippings, ephemera, and correspondence. Files contain a small amount of Herbert M. Rothschild materials as well.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: This subseries follows the earlier arrangement created by the Ethical Culture School archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Materials related to Rothchild's work with the Board of Governors. Topics include by-laws, administrative organization, staff and faculty policies, school finances, year-round programs, and admissions diversity. Also includes copies of 1930s financial reports, and handbooks for parents and teachers, 1950-1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Material relating to criteria for search committees, positions, and Fieldston's administrative structure.

Copies of lecture summaries, essays on education, and an address given by Adler at the bier of Franklin Lewis. Event materials, including ephemera from Adler's fiftieth wedding anniversary celebration. Some correspondence regarding memorials after Adler's death.

did.unittitle: Self-Evaluation Report for New York Association of Independent Schools (2 folders)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Report with history and philosophy of the school, parent survey results, and Board of Governors evaluation. For each school, the 1992 report contains a purpose statement, information about staffing policies, a description of programs and curriculum, and description of the decision-making process. did.unittitle: Subseries VI.A Faculty and administration files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of individual files for faculty and staff. For the majority of individuals, materials consist of one folder relating to their employment and work at the Ethical Culture Schools. Nearly all materials in the series were created between 1920 and 1950. (The small amount of items created in the 1970s through the 1990s are mostly obituaries or memorial items for past faculty.) The series is arranged alphabetically by last name.

Files of teachers and principals are most commonly found, but the series also contains several files for psychologists and guidance counselors, librarians, medical staff (especially dieticians and nurses), facilities staff, secretaries, and business managers. Both 3-School staff and staff from individual schools are included.

Correspondence, both with and regarding the individual, makes up the bulk of the series. Letters typically discuss administrative matters, classroom issues, contracts, salaries, requests for supplies, and facilities issues. The majority of correspondence is internal to the Schools, along with instances of correspondence with vendors or colleagues at other educational institutions. Many correspondence items concern employment, including inquiries into work at the Ethical Culture Schools, requests by Fieldston for references or other information about a prospective employee, or requests for references by other schools. There are some examples of personal correspondence, such as invitations, or notes keeping in touch with past employees.

Other than correspondence, files contain curriculum items, schedules, summer contact information cards, news clippings, ephemera, and classroom materials (syllabi, bibliographies). Obituaries, memorial service programs and other tribute materials are found throughout. There is some discussion of specific students, before 1950.

The personnel files for some individuals do contain substantive materials about the work of their department. In particular, the folders of Henry Kelly (14 folders, 1902-1939), August Klock (7 folders, 1923-1940) contain a good deal of information about the biology department, including the report "The Science Course at Fieldston," 1930. The following files contain information about each department, mostly during the 1930s and early 1940s: Margaret Koch, history; William Kurtz, physical education and athletic programs; Ethel Murphy, math; Alberta Newton, Greek and Latin. The two files of Arthur Richards contain information on the printing shop in the 1920s. Other departments represented include English, ethics, chemistry, fine arts, French, and German.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by last name.

did.unittitle: Record Group 2. Early and defunct schools (1879-1957; 13.17 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record group includes materials for the Ethical Culture School and its programs prior to the opening of the Fieldston campus in 1928. This includes records for the earlier iteration of the school, The Workingman's School, and its evolution to Ethical Culture Schools. The record group also contains records for discontinued early programs: the Summer Play School, the Open Air Department, and the Normal Department for Teacher Training.

Types of materials include ephemera, correspondence, reports, student work, photographs, and news clippings. Board records and administrative records from this era can be found in Record Group 1, and additional ephemera can be found in Record Group 11, Printed matter.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This record group is organized into four series:
Series I. Defunct schools
Series II. Ethical Culture Schools
Series III. Normal Teacher Training Department
Series IV. Normal School student records (RESTRICTED)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes records for early schools and programs that are no longer in existence: the Workingman's School, the Open Air School, and the Summer Play School. (The Branch School was also in operation during this era, but collection does not contain any related records.) These early records mostly consist of ephemera and reports from teachers and principals, along with four scrapbooks compiled by Summer Play School leader Mabel Towne Burnham.

The Open Air Department conducted classes on the roof of the Central Park West Building from the 1910s through the 1920s. The Summer Play School was founded in partnership with the New York Federation for Child Study (later the Child Study Association of America) in 1919, providing summer activities and meals for underprivileged children at the Ethical Culture School building on Central Park West.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Within this series, files are arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Primarily news clippings and ephemera. News items mostly cover the Ethical Culture School, with some on founder Felix Adler, the Society for Ethical Culture and the United Relief Works, and social issues and progressive education generally. Also includes clippings of newspaper ads for the school.
Ephemera also relates to the School, the Society, and Adler. Examples include attendance and enrollment forms, class schedules, parent letters from the School; fliers, invitations, and letterhead from the Society; and a passenger list from Adler's 1891 trip to Antwerp. The scrapbook also contains ephemera and news clippings on the Plymouth School of Applied Ethics (where Adler taught.) The book has been disbound, with pages foldered.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records for the teacher education program founded by the Ethical Culture School in the 1890s. The program consisted of a two-year course until 1933, when it became a three-year course. Its final class graduated in 1939. Ephemera and photographs make up the bulk of the series.

arrangement.p: Within this series, files are arranged in chronological order.

did.unittitle: Series IV. (RESTRICTED) Normal School student records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series consists of individual records for Normal Department teacher trainees from the class of 1919 through the class of 1939. Records date from 1919 to 1978, but the majority of records were created during the years students were enrolled in the program, or soon after.

Nearly all files contain an application for admission (often including letters of recommendation or high school transcripts), acceptance letters, observation reports on teaching sessions, and other documents on performance in the program. Many materials, including transcripts and recommendations sent to prospective employers, relate to student job searches after graduation. Many files also contain applications for scholarships, class schedules, verifications of medical examination or vaccination, marriage announcements and invitations, news clippings (mostly regarding marriages), and photographs. Files for the class of 1933 through 1939 include a small photograph of each student; other photographs are noted at the files level.

Correspondence topics include admission, performance in program, tuition, requests for references, and events in the lives former students who are keeping in touch with faculty.
Records for the classes of 1940 and 1941, along with additional records for the class of 1939, are unprocessed.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically by graduation year, then alphabetically by student last name.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Normal School student records are closed to general access until 2040. To request permission to access these files, contact Ethical Culture Fieldston School's Chief Operating Officer (COO). No access will be permitted to anyone before 2040 without the explicit, written permission of the COO.

Record Group 3. Fieldston School (1925-2012; 18.75 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record group includes materials for the Fieldston School, the secondary school often referred to as the Upper School and later divided into Fieldston Middle and Fieldston Upper. Overall, the series provides information on the administrative and educational work of faculty and staff, as well as the academic and extracurricular life of students in Form I through Form VI. Types of materials include ephemera, correspondence, meeting materials, reports, student work, photographs, and news clippings.

The papers of principals and other senior administrators, including long-time principal Luther Tate can be found in this record group. Evaluations of the schools are also included, most notably the "Eight-Year Study, a 1930s multi-school study on secondary education and college preparation. This record group also contains materials on Fieldston-specific faculty matters and school policies.

Academic programs are represented with annual department reports from the 1930s through 1980s, assorted departmental records, curriculum materials, and some examples of student work. Programs, newsletters, news clippings, and other ephemera cover student athletics, performances (including dance, drama, and music) and student clubs and organizations.

Copies of school newspapers and literary journals, along with additional ephemera relating to school activities, can be found in Record Group 11, Printed matter. Records related to the construction of the Fieldston campus and Tate Library can be found in Record Group 10, Buildings and grounds. Class directories and individual faculty information can be found in Record Group 1. Prior to 1928, secondary education was conducted at the Ethical Culture School in Manhattan, so those earlier records can be found in Record Group 2, Early and defunct schools.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This record group is organized into three series:
Series I. Administrative affairs
Series II. Academic affairs
Series III. Student life

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series relates mostly to administrative matters, including the work of the principal's office, senior administrators, and faculty. It also includes evaluations of and reports on the school, and discussion of other programs and policies affecting the school.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This series is arranged in four subseries:
Subseries I.A. Senior administration
Subseries I.B. Evaluations
Subseries I.C. Faculty
Subseries I.D. Fieldston Upper matters

scopecontent.p: This subseries includes the records of principals (including Luther Tate), other senior administrators, and Fieldston-specific administrative committees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Files of the senior administration, primarily of the offices of Principals Smith and Tate. Includes correspondence, notes, ephemera, schedules, and reports. Subjects: (Faculty) apartments, Apprentices, "Black book" [schedules, rosters, reference information], Budget and purchase orders, Calendar, Class lists, Commission on Secondary Schools, Educational Records Bureau, Junior College Course, Schedules, Social Welfare Activities of New York, State of New York [student testing], Student Council Fund, Testing, Vacation surveys, Work load surveys.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Text of speeches and talks (for example, for graduation or memorials, or to Board of Governors), with drafts. Some teaching materials. Ephemera from 1966 memorial service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tate's correspondence (1929-1965) with Fieldston faculty and staff, parents, prospective students and employees, and administrators at other secondary schools and colleges. Frequent topics include college admissions, student progress, school scheduling and curriculum, facilities, textbooks, admissions to Fieldston, hiring of faculty, donations, discipline, events, and the use of school grounds. Includes a very small amount of personal correspondence, such as medical or car insurance inquiries.

Also contains some records from Tate's time at Fieldston before becoming principal, including correspondence with principal H.W. Smith and a 1929 letter accepting offer of teaching position. 1940s records include discussion of impact of World War II on the schools.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Itineraries, with Tate's summaries of visits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Papers of Spencer Brown, primarily from his teaching and administrative roles prior to becoming principal. Mostly correspondence, including much with Luther Tate, other Fieldston teachers and administrators, parents, and colleagues at other institutions. Correspondence often relates to college admissions, New York State testing, and Fieldston curriculum, with some letters on personal matters or Brown's writing career. Also includes some teaching materials, meeting minutes, congratulatory correspondence on Brown's appointment as principal in 1966, and Selective Service materials in the 1940s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record group contains materials related to the Ethical Culture School in Midtown. Topics covered include school administration and curriculum, and common types of materials include ephemera, correspondence, reports, and student work. Student levels range from kindergarten to grades five or six (depending on the era), with a very small amount of pre-school materials.

This record group only contains materials created after the opening of the Fieldston School campus in 1928; Ethical Culture School records created prior to 1928 can be found in Record Group 2. Additional related materials can be found in Record Group 1 and Record Group 11.

did.unittitle: Record Group 5. Fieldston Lower (1933-2012; 6.5 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record group contains materials related to the Fieldston Lower School, the elementary school on the Fieldston campus. The bulk of materials are related to curriculum and student activities, or the day-to-day activities of the faculty and administration. Substantial information can be found in the 1985 report on Fieldston Lower by the New York Association of Independent Schools, and in annual department reports. Types of items include correspondence, ephemera, reports, teacher instruction materials, along with art and other projects created by students.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This record group is organized into two series:
Series I. Administrative affairs
Series II. Academic affairs and student life

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series primarily contains records of principals and faculty at the Fieldston Lower School. The majority of records relate to administrative matters and faculty activities. Daily faculty bulletins and records of the 1985 study by the New York Association of Independent Schools make up a large portion of the series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series begins with the records of the principal's office, in chronological order. The rest of the series is arranged alphabetically, followed by miscellaneous.

did.unittitle: Record Group 6. Camps and programs (1920s-2008; 1.25 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record group contains materials relating to summer camps and other programs created and managed by the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools. Notably, this includes the Ethical Culture School Camp in Cooperstown, New York, in existence from the 1920s to the 1970s. Records for day camps held on school grounds are also included, along with records for summer programs designed to assist public school students with high school or college preparation. Common types of materials include ephemera, correspondence, reports, and news clippings. Additional information on extracurricular activities and after-school programs can be found in Record Groups 3, 4 and 5. Items relating to the Summer Play School (founded 1919) can be found in Record Group 2.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged chronologically, beginning with Ethical Culture School Camp files, and followed by miscellaneous items.

did.unittitle: Record Group 8. Alumni and alumni-relations (1891-2015; 28.5 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
This record group contains materials related to the alumni of Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools. This includes records of the Alumni Association, internal alumni-relations programs, and the Director of Alumni Affairs, as well as materials on the work and lives of former students. Archival materials donated by alumni are also found here.
Correspondence, meeting materials, news clippings, and ephemera make up most of the record group, along with some photographs and examples of student work. Records date from the 1890s through the 2010s, but the majority of items were created between 1970 and 2010.
Additional alumni fund-raising and alumni-relations records can be found in Record Group 9, Development and Communications and in files of the administration in Record Group 1. Copies of alumni directories and other ephemera can be found in Record Group 11, Printed matter.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This record group is arranged in three series:
Series I: Alumni Association
Series II: Office of Alumni Affairs
Series III: Alumni materials
(Arrangement is based on previous processing efforts by the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools, with additions by the archivist.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records from the Alumni Association, an alumni-led group. Meeting materials for the Association and the Alumni Executive Board make up much of the series, which also contains ephemera, lists of officers and members, and correspondence. Frequent topics include reunions and other social functions, fund-raising, and the relationship of the Alumni Association to the school.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and related papers from the Alumni Association. Subject matter mostly involves membership, payment of dues, events (annual dinners, reunions, social dinners and dances), and coordination with the school and Ethical Culture Society. A large portion of correspondence is from the papers of Robert Eiserman, longtime secretary of the Association. This includes a small amount of correspondence with Felix Adler. Non-correspondence items include early copies of the Association's constitution, lists of members, membership applications, ephemera, and reports from the Association's Executive Committee or Treasurer. 1909 correspondence includes responses to an alumni questionnaire on the value of scholarships.

did.unittitle: Series II. Office of Alumni Affairs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II contains records of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School's own work with alumni, through the Office of Alumni Affairs. Records were primarily created during the tenure of Director of Alumni Affairs Toby Himmel. Most of the material in this series relates to events (such as reunions, homecomings, and speaker series), alumni mentorship and diversity programs, and fund-raising. Records of the Office's work in establishing and maintaining a school archive, and tracking developments in the lives of alumni, are also found in this series.

Subseries II.B: Archives and alumni information

Record Group 9. Development and communications (1885-2009; 17.25 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Record Group 9 consists of materials related to development and communications efforts for the Ethical Culture Fieldston School. Subject matter includes development appeals, the management of gifts and funds, school programs, public relations, and strategic planning.
It contains a small amount of materials from the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, but the vast majority of records were created after the establishment a dedicated program for fund-raising and publicity in the 1950s. Types of materials include correspondence, reports, meeting materials, press releases, ephemera, and news clippings. Files related to the celebration and publicity of the school's various anniversary celebrations can also be found in this record group.
Records related to fund-raising for the construction of new buildings, especially Tate Library, can be found in Record Group 10, Buildings and grounds. Administrative and Board of Governors materials in Record Group 1 also often involve development or public relations efforts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This record group is arranged in three series:
Series I: Fund-raising and publicity before 1950
Series II: Fund-raising and publicity, 1950s-1970s
Series III: Development and communications, 1980-2000s

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Series II contains records from the administrative office for fund-raising and publicity from the 1950s through the 1970s. This era saw the establishment of the Ethical Fieldston Fund and the Development Committee, with regular appeals to alumni and parents, and simultaneously, the creation of the Public Relations Working Committee and the publication of the 1954 report, "A Public Relations Program for the Ethical Culture Schools."
Fund-raising materials include copies of appeals, committee and meeting materials, reports on campaigns and funds, and correspondence. Publicity efforts, often managed by the same staff, are represented in committee materials, correspondence, and a good deal of press releases, which were created frequently in this era. Background materials on various school programs, as well as some general school administrative records can also be found in this record group.
Related records can be found in Record Group 1, Subseries IV.C., the records of the editorial and publicity assistant to Director Victoria Wagner.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:

did.unittitle: Record Group 10. Buildings and grounds (1882-2005; 26.65 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The Buildings and grounds series primarily contains materials related to the construction of Ethical Culture School buildings, both in Manhattan and the Bronx. A large portion of the record group is devoted to the planning and construction of Tate Library on the Fieldston campus in the 1960s and 1970s. Types of materials include correspondence, meeting materials, ephemera, government documents, news clippings, press releases, photographs, and architectural drawings.

Records related to fundraising efforts, especially for the construction of the Midtown Ethical Culture School building during the 1920s and the Tate Library during the 1960s, are also included. Architectural drawings and diagrams are generally oversize. For the most part, architectural images appear to have been produced for display or general information, not for use during construction.

did.unittitle: Record Group 13. Ethics Department and the Society for Ethical Culture (1901-1999; 7.5 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
This record group contains materials related to the Society for Ethical Culture, its shared philosophies with the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, and ethics program curriculum. The Society for Ethical Culture was established in 1876 by Felix Adler, who founded the Workingman's School two years later. In 1895, the Society took governance of the newly named Ethical Culture School. Since 1996, the Society and School have been officially separate organizations.
Based on the Society's teaching, the ethics program was intended to guide students both in their personal lives and their places in the greater world. It was described in 1984 as "based on the personal, social, and intellectual development of our students and responding to the moral issues that they meet in experiences."
Types of materials include correspondence, reports, ephemera (produced both by the Society and ECFS), legal documents, meeting minutes, teacher guides, and curriculum materials. Records were created throughout the 20th century, but the bulk of materials are dated between the 1970s and 1990s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This record group is arranged in two series:
Series I. The Society for Ethical Culture
Series II. Ethics Department

did.unittitle: Series I. Society for Ethical Culture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Records in this series involve the relationship between the Society for Ethical Culture and the Ethical Culture Fieldston School. Subjects include the influence of Society teachings on the School's philosophy, the use of shared spaces in the Central Park West building, the administration of shared funds, and the formal financial separation of the two organizations in the 1990s.
It also includes papers of Algernon Black, an ECFS alumni and long-time leader of the Society, as well as early 1990s records related to the separation, from the office of Head of School Jeanne Amster.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in chronological order, following earlier processing efforts.

Files also include Ethical Culture Society committee meeting minutes and correspondence with Luther Tate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
This series contains records of the Ethics program at all grade levels of the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools. The Ethics curriculum is built on humanistic teachings, with subjects including interpersonal relationships, mental and physical health, current events, history, religion, and moral theory. There is a focus on teaching through examples in myths, folklore, and fiction throughout the program.
As Educational Director Dr. V.T. Thayer wrote of the program's goals in 1936, "One, that children be led through the school to discover and to develop their unique possibilities of mind and character; and second that their growth should proceed at all times in sensitive response to fundamental aspects of the society in which they live and move and have their being."
The majority of records were created between 1979 and 1990, during the tenure of Head of School Howard Radest. (Radest also managed the Ethics program in this era, and was involved in the leadership of the Society for Ethical Culture.) It also includes printed copies of stories and texts from throughout the 20th century.

scopecontent.p: Copies of "The Fieldston Ethics Reader," and "Exploring Ethics through Children's Literature." Copies of "Can We Teach Ethics?" and "The Devil and Secular Humanism" by Howard Radest, both with inscriptions to "Janet."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
This record group contains photographs and photographic materials. Photographic prints make up most of the record group, which also contains negatives, slides, and discs with digital images. Image content includes students, staff, faculty, alumni, buildings, arts programs, athletic programs, and events.
Both amateur and professional photographs are included. Many photographs were taken by faculty and staff, with some donated by families and alumni. Dates of creation range from 1887 to 2016, with the bulk of materials created in the second half of the twentieth-century. A small amount of photographs can also be found in other record groups, where noted.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This record group is arranged in five series:
Series I. Ethical Culture Fieldston photo archive
Series II. Scrapbooks and albums
Series III. Photographs after 1980
Series IV. Communications collections
Series V. Oversize materials and special formats

did.unittitle: Series I. Ethical Culture Fieldston photo archive

The series contains images from throughout the school's history, including the Workingman's School and Free Kindergarten. A small number of relevant photographs have been added to the original collection.
Content descriptions include original folder titles.

did.unittitle: Record Group 15. (RESTRICTED) Audiovisual (1950s-2008, undated; 26.42 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
The Audiovisual record group contains audio or moving visual recordings. Types of materials include film reels, audio tape, cassette tapes, VHS and other video cassettes, and vinyl records. The title or identifier for each individual item is listed in this inventory.
The majority of content has been captured by amateurs, such as school employees, with some professional recordings. For all materials in this record group, audio and visual content has been identified solely by labels or other written description accompanying objects (not by playback).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This record group is arranged in three series:
Series I. Film
Series II. VHS
Series III. Audio recordings

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Note that the audiovisual material in this record group is restricted due to its fragility and because the New-York Historical Society lacks the necessary playback equipment. Patrons wishing to view or listen to any of the material in this record group should contact the curator of manuscripts at manuscripts @nyhistory.org

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains film reels, including Super 8 format (noted at the file level). A small number of earlier films have been converted to video, and can be found in Series II.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in chronological order.

did.unittitle: Anniversary film Part I / Third Grade Cook-out - October 1954

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 21 reels of film, with previous inventory in box (which includes some reels in box 347. Dated reels are labeled: Trinity vs. EMA, 1959 (2 rolls); Fieldston vs. Friends, 1961 (2 rolls); Fieldston vs. Carteret, 1962; Fieldston vs. Brunswick, 1965; Fieldston vs. Locust Valley, 1965 (2 rolls); Fieldston vs. Collegiate, 1970 (color); Fieldston vs. Brunswick, 1970 (color). Undated reels are labeled: Fieldston vs. Trinity (2 reels) and a third reel of a different Trinity game; Fieldston vs. Englewood (2 rolls); Fieldston vs. Woodmere; Fieldston vs. Locust Valley. There are also 4 unlabeled reels, but detached labels in the box suggest that one of these is Fieldston vs. McBurney and another is Fieldston vs. Locust Valley, 1967 ("with George Martens, faculty member"). A third is possibly St. Bernard's (1960), listed on the original inventory as poor, and the fourth may be another Woodmere.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Continuation of film reels from original inventory list in box 346. This box holds 5 undated reels: Fieldston H.S. (2 rolls); Fieldston School (2 rolls), and one unlabeled roll. Also, two Sony video cassettes from 1979: Fieldston vs. Englewood and Fieldston vs. Dalton. Also a third Sony videotape dated 11/10/78 with unclear label.

scopecontent.p: This series contains digital formats, including CDs, DVDs, floppy disks, and Digital Audio Tape (DAT). Content includes audiovisual recordings, digital photographs, and other documents.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series begins with CDs and DVDs, followed by other digital formats.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The digital media is currently restricted from use in order to ensure that the files are not accidentally corrupted. N-YHS will be developing procedures to properly handle digital media and this content will be opened in the future after those procedures are established and implemented.

did.unittitle: Record Group 18. (RESTRICTED) Student records (circa 1910-1940; 70 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some student records from the early decades of the twentieth century are held in the collection, dating through about 1940. These include student files from the midtown school and the Fieldston campus. This record group does not include student records from the Normal School (last graduating class was in 1941), which are found in Record Group 2. These student records are all closed to general access until 2040. New-York Historical Society generally holds no student records for graduating classes from 1940 and later, though a very few random files from the early 1940s appear to have been interfiled with the earlier files. The files include grades, qualitative evaluations, permission slips, correspondence, notes on college acceptances, etc. The files include some documents from years after the student left ECFS such as requests for transcripts, clippings (regarding marriages and the like), and other individual alumni matters.

There are three sets of records: files for graduating classes up to 1936, files for graduating classes of 1937-1939, and index cards of records for students. Each set of files are in alphabetical order by student surname. The index cards were originally labeled as "withdrawn students through 1936," but there are cards for students through 1940 (and a very few from the early 1940s) and there are cards for students who graduated from tthe schools.
The index card files are clearly incomplete as seen by the obvious gaps in the alphabetical sequence. It is not known how complete the other two sets of files are.

To request permission to access any student historical records, contact Ethical Culture Fieldston School's Chief Operating Officer (COO). No access will be permitted without the explicit, written permission of the COO.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The record group is arranged such that the three sets of files (to 1936, 1937 to about 1940, and index cards) are boxed in their original order as found. The files are unprocessed and remain in their original folders, which are fragile, as are some of the documents in the files.

The index cards were rehoused from their original deteriorated boxes, but the original labels were retained, principally to help highlight the gaps in the records. The number of cards per student ranges widely, from a single card to perhaps dozens. Many, though not all, of these multiple card sets were originally held together by rubber bands, which have all dried out and crumbled apart. Consequently, care needs to be taken in using the cards to ensure that they do not get mixed up. However, many of the cards were already found mixed up during re-boxing in 2019; the archivist attempted to ensure that the order of names in the boxes were generally correct, but users should not expect the cards to be in perfect sequence within a particular student's cards or across student cards. This will be especially so for students with identical names, students with cards that referred to them by different names (e.g., Robert and Bob), and cards with variant surname spellings for the same student (e.g., Cohen/Cohn/Cone).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The record group is closed to general access until 2040. To request permission to access any student historical records, contact Ethical Culture Fieldston School's Chief Operating Officer (COO). No access will be permitted to anyone before 2040 without the explicit, written permission of Fieldston's COO.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box includes student files found after the above boxes were packed at N-YHS. They were found together and it is not clear why they had not been filed alphabetically by ECFS with the other records. Names (class/course completion/departure year) in this box are: John (Jack) Adler (1939), Virginia Boyle (1936), Vivian Brecher (1934), Anna Chess (1929), Myron Coler (1930), Naomi Diamant (1925), Frances Field (1933), Estelle Frankfurter (1913), Janice Hubshman (1938), Stanley Kallman (1939), Gordon Kerby (1934), Angela Kitzinger (1921), Marjory Leve (1914), Evelyn Levy (1925), John Lewis (1927), Richard Machol (1929), Margaret Mather (1929), David Mintz (1939), Joyce Morganstern (1939), Judith Morganstern (1939), William Salant (1933), George Sanders (1930), Marjorie Schecter (1934), Robert Simon (1915), Robert Simons (1928), Richard Sprayregen (1939), Mirian Spectorsky (1921), Richard George Stein (1932), Elizabeth Stern (1929), Claire Weinstein/Winston (1938), Susan Wimpfheimer (1932), Arthur Winogrand (1937), Sybil Winsten (1939), Charles Wolfe (1937), Eleanor Wolfe (1937), Robert Wolff (1938), Jean Woolf (1939), Flora Wovschin (1939), Barbara Wright (1938), Jane Wright (1938), Lester Wyner (1939), Cynthia Zimmerman (1939).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: While the archive was still at Fieldston, staff apparently identified the files of particular students to pull from the general run of student records to hold separately. At N-YHS these files were not re-integrated into the alpha files, but kept together as found during processing. Those separated files are in this box 379. The student names (class year) are: Louis Aborn (1930), Mischa (sp?)
